subject: polity
title: Federal vs Unitary System - Comprehensive Comparison

rows.federalSystem: **Dual polity** - Power divided between Central (Union) and State (Regional) governments by Constitution
rows.unitarySystem: **Single polity** - All power vests in Central government; Regional units subordinate to Centre

rows.federalSystem: **Constitution** - Both Centre and States derive powers from Constitution
rows.unitarySystem: **Centre** - States/regions derive power from Centre (delegated authority)

rows.federalSystem: **Divided** - Sovereignty shared between Centre and States (dual sovereignty)
rows.unitarySystem: **Undivided** - Sovereignty vests entirely in Central government

rows.federalSystem: **Written and rigid** - Federal structure defined in Constitution; Difficult to amend federal provisions (need state consent)
rows.unitarySystem: **May be written or unwritten** - Can be flexible (like UK); Easy to change governance structure

rows.federalSystem: **Constitutional distribution** - Powers clearly divided (Union, State, Concurrent Lists in 7th Schedule)
rows.unitarySystem: **No distribution** - Centre can allocate/withdraw powers to/from states at will

rows.federalSystem: **High autonomy** - States have independent powers; Cannot be taken away by Centre (except emergency)
rows.unitarySystem: **Low/No autonomy** - Regions subordinate; Centre controls; Can be dissolved/merged

rows.federalSystem: **Divided** - Separate subjects for Union and States (Union List - 97 subjects, State List - 61 subjects, Concurrent - 47)
rows.unitarySystem: **Centralized** - Centre has exclusive legislative power; Can legislate on all subjects

rows.federalSystem: **Dual executive** - Union govt for Union subjects; State govt for State subjects; Independent executive authority
rows.unitarySystem: **Single executive** - Central govt executive authority over entire country; States are agents of Centre

rows.federalSystem: **Dual/Integrated** - Federal courts (Supreme Court) + State courts (High Courts); Interpret federal-state disputes
rows.unitarySystem: **Single hierarchy** - Unified court system under central control

rows.federalSystem: **Requires state consent** - Federal provisions (Centre-State relations, SC/HC, 7th Schedule) need 50% state ratification (Art 368)
rows.unitarySystem: **Centre alone** - Central govt/parliament can amend without consulting states

rows.federalSystem: **Divided** - Centre has certain taxes (customs, GST, income tax); States have others (land revenue, excise); Concurrent (GST)
rows.unitarySystem: **Centralized** - Central govt controls taxation; May share revenue with regions

rows.federalSystem: **Dual** (USA, Switzerland) or **Single** (India, Canada) - May have both national and state citizenship
rows.unitarySystem: **Single** - Only national citizenship

rows.federalSystem: **Judicial resolution** - Supreme Court adjudicates disputes (Art 131 - original jurisdiction); Interstate disputes also (Art 262)
rows.unitarySystem: **No mechanism** - Centre's decision final; No dispute as states are subordinate

rows.federalSystem: **Rigid** - Constitutional changes to federal structure difficult; Need states' consent; Protects federal balance
rows.unitarySystem: **Flexible** - Easy to change governance; Parliament/Centre can modify structure anytime

rows.federalSystem: **Complex** - Two levels of administration; Coordination needed; May cause delays
rows.unitarySystem: **Simple** - Single chain of command; Efficient; Quick decision-making

rows.federalSystem: **Large, diverse countries** - Geographically large; Diverse population (linguistic, cultural, ethnic diversity); USA, Canada, India, Australia, Brazil
rows.unitarySystem: **Small, homogeneous countries** - Small area; Uniform population; UK, France, Japan, China, New Zealand

rows.federalSystem:
• Protects diversity
• Prevents tyranny (checks and balances)
• Local governance (better understanding of local needs)
• Federating units retain identity
• Diffusion of power
rows.unitarySystem:
• Strong Centre - Unity
• Quick decisions
• Simple and efficient
• Uniform laws
• Lower administrative cost

rows.federalSystem:
• Complex and expensive
• Slow decision-making
• Centre-State conflicts
• Duplication of functions
• May lead to regionalism
rows.unitarySystem:
• Risk of tyranny
• Ignores diversity
• Distant from local needs
• Over-centralization
• Regional aspirations suppressed

rows.federalSystem: **Federal structure may be suspended** - In India, during National Emergency, India becomes unitary (Art 356); States lose autonomy
rows.unitarySystem: **No change** - Already centralized; Emergency just strengthens Centre further

rows.federalSystem:
**Classical federal**: USA, Australia, Canada, Brazil, Switzerland, Germany, Argentina
**Quasi-federal**: India (federal + unitary features)
rows.unitarySystem: **Examples**: UK, France, Japan, China, Italy, Spain, New Zealand, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh

indianContext: **Art 1**: India is 'Union of States' (NOT 'Federation of States')
**Why 'Union'?**: States have no right to secede; Permanent union (unlike USA where states have theoretical secession right)
**K.C. Wheare**: India is 'Quasi-federal' - Federal in structure, Unitary in spirit
**Granville Austin**: India is 'Co-operative federalism' - Cooperation between Centre and States
indianFederalFeatures: **2. Dual polity** - Union and States (Art 1, Part I)
**3. Division of powers** - 7th Schedule (Union, State, Concurrent Lists)
**4. Supremacy of Constitution** - Constitutional supremacy, not Parliament
**5. Rigid Constitution** - Federal provisions need state ratification (Art 368)
indianUnitaryFeatures: **1. Strong Centre** - Union List (97) > State List (61); Residuary powers to Union (Art 248)
**2. Single Constitution** - No separate state constitutions (unlike USA)
**3. Single citizenship** - No state citizenship (unlike USA)
**4. Integrated judiciary** - Single hierarchy; SC apex; HCs under SC
**5. Emergency provisions** - Art 352, 356, 360 (Centre can suspend federal structure)
**6. Governor** - Centre's agent in states (Art 153-162); Appointed by President
**7. All India Services** - IAS, IPS, IFS controlled by Centre (Art 312)
**8. Centre can legislate on State List** - During emergency (Art 250), national interest (Art 249), interstate agreement (Art 252)
**9. State boundaries** - Centre can change by simple majority (Art 3)
**10. Parliament's supremacy** - Can override state laws on Concurrent List (Art 254)
**11. Financial dependence** - States depend on Centre for grants (Art 275, 282)
quasiFederal: **K.C. Wheare (1953)**: India is 'Quasi-federal' - Neither truly federal nor unitary
**Reasoning**: Strong unitary features (emergency, single citizenship, strong Centre) make it lean towards unitary
**BUT**: Federal structure (division of powers, dual polity, written Constitution) make it federal
**Conclusion**: **'Federal in normal times, Unitary during emergency'**
scView: **State of West Bengal v Union (1963)**: SC observed Indian Constitution is 'federal' (division of powers)
**S.R. Bommai (1994)**: SC emphasized federal structure is **basic feature** of Constitution; Cannot be destroyed
**Kesavananda Bharati (1973)**: Federalism is part of basic structure
**Judicial trend**: SC has been protecting federalism through interpretations (Art 356 abuse curtailed, states' rights protected)
examTips: **Most asked**: Why India is 'Quasi-federal'? (Federal + Unitary features)
**Federal features**: Division of powers, written Constitution, dual polity, rigid (need states for federal provisions)
**Unitary features**: Strong Centre, single citizenship, emergency, Governor, All India Services, integrated judiciary
**Explain**: 10-15 points comparison; Then explain India's position (quasi-federal)

data.summary: **Federal vs Unitary**: **Federal** = Dual polity; Power divided by Constitution; States have autonomy; Written and rigid; Dual executive/judiciary; Suitable for large, diverse countries (USA, Canada, India). **Unitary** = Single polity; Power vests in Centre; States subordinate; Flexible; Single executive; Suitable for small, homogeneous countries (UK, France, Japan). **India**: **'Quasi-federal'** (K.C. Wheare) - Federal in structure (division of powers, dual polity, written Constitution, rigid) + Unitary in spirit (strong Centre, single citizenship, emergency, Governor, All India Services). **Art 1**: India is 'Union of States'. **Federal in normal times, Unitary during emergency**. **SC view**: Federalism is **basic structure** (S.R. Bommai 1994).
